elements.content: A partially fluorinated, angular tetracarboxylic acid linker (H 4 L) incorporating a pendant amine moiety forms a three-dimensional Zn­(II) framework, 1. The structure consists of paddle-wheel Zn2(CO2)4 secondary building units (SBUs) and Zn12(CO2)24 supramolecular building blocks (SBBs). Thermal stability of 1 is found to be low. However, it undergoes transmetalation reaction with Cu­(II) at room temperature without losing crystallinity affording an isostructural framework, 1 Cu . Framework 1 Cu is thermally robust and allows generation of the solvent-free porous framework 1 Cu ′ upon activation with coordinatively unsaturated metal centers. Framework 1 Cu ′ exhibits water stability and at 77 K, adsorbs 2.56 wt % of H2 up to 1 bar that significantly increases to 4.01 wt % at 13 bar. Also, this framework gives a high adsorption of 164.70 cc/g of CH4 (11.7 wt %) at 303 K and 60 bar. The channel surfaces decorated with −NH2 group and unsaturated metal centers in 1 Cu ′ allow a promising 36.4 wt % of CO2 adsorption at 1 bar and 273 K. Moreover, it exhibits pronounced selectivity of CO2 adsorption over N2 and H2 at 273 K. Finally, the versatility of 1 Cu ′ is shown by its excellent heterogeneous catalytic activity in the Biginelli coupling reactions involving an aldehyde, urea, and ethylacetoacetate to afford dihydroprimidinones.

elements.content: A 3D, thermally less-stable Zn­(II)-framework (1) undergoes single-crystal to single-crystal transmetalation with Cu­(II) to afford isostructural 1 Cu . Unlike 1, the Cu­(II) analogue is thermally stable and can be activated by heating to get 1 Cu ′, which exhibits water stability and adsorbs 2.56 wt % of H2 at 1 bar. It exhibits pronounced CO2 selectivity over N2 and H2 and catalyzes the three-component Biginelli coupling reaction.

elements.content: The rapid buildup of carbon dioxide from anthropogenic activities is becoming an important environmental issue because of global warming. This has raised the interest for developing efficient adsorbents for CO2 capture and its sequestration from flue-gas and other sources. The conventional CO2 capture and sequestration technologies, based on the alkanolamine-based wet scrubbing systems, require high temperature and suffer from the leakage of amines to the environment. Alternatively, emission of CO2 can be reduced by utilizing clean-energy sources such as hydrogen gas, which is lightweight and burns cleanly to produce water, a green byproduct. In this respect, porous metal organic frameworks (PMOFs) are highly promising materials for CO2 capture and H2 storage applications and have drawn enormous research interests during the past decade. Situation becomes more attractive when, in a PMOF, metal clusters act as nodes and one or more solvent molecules are bonded to metal ions belonging to a node. Quite frequently, the framework remains intact in these cases, upon removal of the lattice and metal-bound solvent molecules to provide a highly porous structure with open metal sites. This can lead to enhancement of gas adsorption. Besides, incorporation of basic side groups in the linker can increase the selectivity of gas adsorption. Furthermore, presence of fluorines in the linker not only improve H2 storage capacity of the PMOF but also increase its stability in humid conditions underlying the importance of designing fluorinated frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rapid buildup of carbon dioxide from anthropogenic activities is becoming an important environmental issue because of global warming. This has raised the interest for developing efficient adsorbents for CO2 capture and its sequestration from flue-gas and other sources. The conventional CO2 capture and sequestration technologies, based on the alkanolamine-based wet scrubbing systems, require high temperature and suffer from the leakage of amines to the environment. Alternatively, emission of CO2 can be reduced by utilizing clean-energy sources such as hydrogen gas, which is lightweight and burns cleanly to produce water, a green byproduct. In this respect, porous metal organic frameworks (PMOFs) are highly promising materials for CO2 capture and H2 storage applications and have drawn enormous research interests during the past decade. Situation becomes more attractive when, in a PMOF, metal clusters act as nodes and one or more solvent molecules are bonded to metal ions belonging to a node. Quite frequently, the framework remains intact in these cases, upon removal of the lattice and metal-bound solvent molecules to provide a highly porous structure with open metal sites. This can lead to enhancement of gas adsorption. Besides, incorporation of basic side groups in the linker can increase the selectivity of gas adsorption. Furthermore, presence of fluorines in the linker not only improve H2 storage capacity of the PMOF but also increase its stability in humid conditions underlying the importance of designing fluorinated frameworks.

elements.content: Given that optimal CO2 capture and H2 storage demand PMOFs with high thermal stability and permanent porosity, carboxylate-based linkers are of predominant interest, as they allow easy fabrication. However, the formation of water/moisture stable carboxylate MOFs is still challenging, since they often suffer from the hydrolysis of weak M–O bonds, besides water molecules occupying the voids. Subsequently, recent efforts in this field have been directed to obtain desired MOFs with stability against water vapor. Transmetalation of the pristine MOF (such as Zn2+) with a less labile metal ion (such as Cu2+) without losing crystallinity is a fascinating yet challenging technique that might afford more stable frameworks. Furthermore, single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transmetalation allows achieving multifunctional MOFs that are often not accessible by direct solvothermal methods. Recent studies have revealed that PMOFs built with multimetal clusters as nodes, known as the secondary building units (SBUs), can tolerate such transmetalation processes, while preserving structural integrity and single crystallinity.

However, the formation of water/moisture stable carboxylate MOFs is still challenging, since they often suffer from the hydrolysis of weak M-O bonds, besides water molecules occupying the voids. Subsequently, recent efforts in this field have been directed to obtain desired MOFs with stability against water vapor. Transmetalation of the pristine MOF (such as Zn2+) with a less labile metal ion (such as Cu2+) without losing crystallinity is a fascinating yet challenging technique that might afford more stable frameworks. Furthermore, single-crystal to single-crystal (SC-SC) transmetalation allows achieving multifunctional MOFs that are often not accessible by direct solvothermal methods. Recent studies have revealed that PMOFs built with multimetal clusters as nodes, known as the secondary building units (SBUs), can tolerate such transmetalation processes, while preserving structural integrity and single crystallinity.

elements.content: Considering the above points, we designed a tetracarboxylate-based linker (H 4 L; a) having amine and fluorine moieties as functional organic sites to build a PMOF with Zn­(II) ions on the following rationale: (i) while terminal isophthalate moieties prefer paddle-wheel SBUs, the bent nature of the ligand favors construction of supramolecular building blocks (SBBs), (ii) four carboxylic groups in H 4 L are likely to form a multiple-pore system, (iii) the sterically constrained −NH2 groups should preclude metal coordination and act as Lewis basic CO2 interaction sites, and (iv) presence of fluorine moiety in the framework not only improves the H2 storage capacity but can also increase the MOF stability under humid conditions.

elements.content: Using the linker H 4 L, we report the formation of a Zn­(II) framework 1 based on paddle-wheel Zn2(CO2)4 SBUs and Zn12(CO2)24 SBBs. This framework is found to be thermally unstable. However, it readily undergoes SC-SC transmetalation at room temperature (RT) to form the isostructural 1 Cu , which is thermally robust and can be activated to produce guest-free framework 1 Cu ′. Framework 1 Cu ′ exhibits significant adsorption of H2 gas at 77 K and a remarkable 36.4 wt % of CO2 with pronounced CO2 selectivity over N2 and H2 at 1 bar and 273 K. In addition, the −NH2 functionalized pores and presence of exposed metal sites in 1 Cu ′ render this framework to act as an excellent heterogeneous catalyst. Of particular interest are the Biginelli condensation reactions involving urea, ethylacetoacetate, and an aromatic aldehyde to afford dihydroprimidinones, which is an important product with relevance in pharmaceutical industry such as potassium channel antagonist, antibacterial activity, in mitotic kinesin inhibition, antihypertensive agents, and so on.

Experimental Section

Materials

Reagent grade chemicals 2,6-dibromo-4-fluoroaniline (98%), 1-bromo-3,5-dimethylbenzene (97%), trimethyl borate (99%), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98%), and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (99%) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. All the solvents were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals (India) and were freshly purified prior to use.

elements.content:
The details of physicochemical characterization and single-crystal X-ray investigation are given in the .

Synthetic Methodology

The tetracarboxylic acid ligand H 4 L was synthesized following a reported procedure as illustrated in .

Synthesis of Tetraester (<bold>III</bold>)

To a 15 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) solution of 2,6-dibromo-4-fluoroaniline (1 g, 0.004 mol) and (3,5-bis­(ethoxycarbonyl)­phenyl) boronic acid (2.39 g, 0.009 mol), a 10 mL aqueous solution of Na2CO3 (2.12 g, 0.02 mol) and palladium acetate (10 mg) was added. The mixture was allowed to heat at 80 °C for 8 h and then cooled to room temperature. Upon extraction with ethyl acetate, it was washed thrice with water and passed through anhydrous Na2SO4. Removal of solvent in a rotary evaporator afforded the crude product as a yellow solid. It was purified using silica gel (100–200 mesh) column chromatography with ethyl acetate/n-hexane (1:9, v/v) as the eluent that gave ∼600 mg of light yellow solid of III (yield ≈ 29%). mp: 175 °C (uncorrected); 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) = 1.42 (t, 12H), 3.55 (s, 2H) 4.43 (q, 8H), 6.92 (s, 2H), 8.34 (d, 4H), 8.69 (d, 2H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) = 14.43, 29.78, 61.61, 118.67, 126.28, 129.73, 130.62, 131.81, 134.59, 140.21, 165.75. Anal. Calcd (%) for C30H30FNO8: C, 65.33; H, 5.48; N, 2.54. Found: C, 65.50; H, 5.75; N, 2.50.

elements.content: The tetra-ester was hydrolyzed by heating at 80 °C with concentrated H2SO4 (96%) in methanol medium with vigorous stirring overnight. Then 10 mL of water was added dropwise at a slow rate to keep the reaction temperature within ∼95 °C. After it was heated 24 h further, it was poured into the crushed ice to obtain a white precipitate. The precipitate was collected and washed thoroughly with water to remove H2SO4. Synthesis of H4L

The tetra-ester was hydrolyzed by heating at 80 °C with concentrated H2SO4 (96%) in methanol medium with vigorous stirring overnight. Then 10 mL of water was added dropwise at a slow rate to keep the reaction temperature within ~95 °C. After it was heated 24 h further, it was poured into the crushed ice to obtain a white precipitate. The precipitate was collected and washed thoroughly with water to remove H2SO4. The white product was dried to obtain 600 mg (~96%) of the tetracarboxylic acid H  4  L. mp >300 °C; 1H NMR (500 MHz, deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6)): δ (ppm) = 4.35 (s, 2H), 7.08 (d, 2H), 8.19 (d, 4H), 8.44 (d, 2H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ (ppm) = 122.88, 130.85, 133.99, 135.61, 137.24, 139.26, 145.52, 147.11, 171.89. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS): m/z (100%) 438.0605 [M-1]-. Anal. Calcd (%) for C22H14FNO8: C, 60.14; H, 3.21; N, 3.19. Found: C, 60.50; H, 3.50; N, 3.28.

When cooled to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C h–1, colorless, block-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained in ∼50% yield. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR; KBr, cm–1): 3447b, 3094s, 2929s, 1657s, 1525s, 1438m, 1107s, 623s. Anal. Calcd (%) for C37H53FN6O17Zn2: C, 44.28; H, 5.32; N, 8.37. De Novo Synthesis of 1  Cu  

Framework 1  Cu  could be synthesized solvothermally albeit in low yields (<10%). The best result was obtained when Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (25 mg, 0.10 mmol) and H  4  L (20 mg, 0.05 mmol) were heated solvothermally at 90 °C for 48 h in the mixed solvent system of 2 mL of DMF, 1 mL of H2O, and 0.1 mL of concentrated HCl.

elements.content: The compound {[Zn2(L)­(H2O)2]·(6DMF)·(2H2O)} n (1) is found to be air-stable and insoluble in common organic solvents or water. A comparison between experimental and simulated powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S8 in the ) confirmed the bulk-phase purity of 1. It crystallizes in the hexagonal system with P63/mmc space group (Table S1 in the ). The asymmetric unit comprises of a quarter of the ligand, a Zn­(II) ion, and a water molecule (with 0.5 occupancy). The coordination geometry of the Zn­(II) ion is distorted square-pyramidal. Four carboxylate O atoms from different L units are ligated equatorially, while the apical position is occupied by O atom of a water molecule. The isophthalate groups of the ligand facilitate the formation of paddle-wheel {Zn2(CO2)4} as the SBUs (c). As depicted in d, three L 4– ligands link six such SBUs to produce Zn12(CO2)24 polyhedron (combination of two triangular faces and three square faces) as the SBB.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The compound {[Zn2(L)(H2O)2]⋅(6DMF)⋅(2H2O)} n  (1) is found to be air-stable and insoluble in common organic solvents or water. A comparison between experimental and simulated powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S8 in the ) confirmed the bulk-phase purity of 1. It crystallizes in the hexagonal system with P63/mmc space group (Table S1 in the ). The asymmetric unit comprises of a quarter of the ligand, a Zn(II) ion, and a water molecule (with 0.5 occupancy). The coordination geometry of the Zn(II) ion is distorted square-pyramidal. Four carboxylate O atoms from different L units are ligated equatorially, while the apical position is occupied by O atom of a water molecule. The isophthalate groups of the ligand facilitate the formation of paddle-wheel {Zn2(CO2)4} as the SBUs (c). As depicted in d, three L 4- ligands link six such SBUs to produce Zn12(CO2)24 polyhedron (combination of two triangular faces and three square faces) as the SBB.

elements.content: The core cavity of this SBB can be accessed either through two triangular faces or three square faces (d). Considering atom-to-atom distance, the spherical diameter of every polyhedron is found to be ∼5.53 Å, while the dimension of the triangular window approximates to 5.08 Å. As depicted in b, the overall three-dimensional (3D) packing with the 4,4-c net ( ssa topology) in 1 (Figure S9 in the ) results from the association of six Zn12(CO2)24 SBBs. To our delight, the functional NH2 and F moiety in the framework are free and focused inside and outside of the triangular cavity, respectively. The highly disordered lattice solvent molecules cannot be mapped crystallographically, and the solvent content is confirmed from the combined input of thermogravimetric and elemental analyses. The results are in well-accordance with the PLATON calculated void volume (4648 Å3, 65.13%). Framework 1 is unstable beyond 50 °C, as evidenced from the variable-temperature PXRD (VTPXRD) patterns (Figure S10 in the ). Even exchanges with other low-boiling solvents like MeOH, EtOH, Me2CO, CHCl3, or CH2Cl2, followed by activation under mild conditions, do not help. Given that ligand field stabilization energy is absent for a Zn2+ ion (d10 electron configuration), removal of the metal-bound water ligand immediately leads to complete rupture of the framework in 1. Clearly, the unstable nature of 1 precludes obtaining an open framework structure for potential gas-storage applications.

elements.content: To our understanding, employment of Cu­(II) SBUs should be fruitful, because unlike Zn­(II), a d9 electronic state possesses ligand field stabilization energy. As the axial water ligand will be removed upon desolvation, the four coordination at the Cu­(II) center will still hold a relatively stable configuration. Existence of large channels and availability of Zn2(CO2)4 SBUs and Zn12(CO2)24 SBBs provide us a platform to explore postsynthetic transmetalation in 1. Indeed, the crystals slowly change from colorless to green-blue in 24 h, when kept in DMF solution of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.05 M) at RT. The electron paramagnetic resonance spectrum of green-blue crystals demonstrates a successful metal replacement (Figure S12 in the ). Monitoring of the metal-exchange kinetics by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy revealed 70% and 95% replacement of Cu2+ in 2 and 6 d, respectively, while complete exchange took 7 d to occur (Figure S15 in the ). This is further supported by the X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy. The morphology of the pristine crystals was preserved throughout the metal-exchange process as corroborated from the optical microscopic observation (Figure S11 in the ). X-ray crystallographic investigation of the (Table S1 in the ) transmetalated product reveals identical structure (Figure S13 in the ) to that of 1, holding the molecular formula {[Cu2(L)­(H2O)2]·(7DMF)·(1H2O)} n (1 Cu ). However, the M···O distance increases from 1.965(4) Å in 1 to 2.144(6) Å in 1 Cu (Table S2 in the ). The bulk phase transformation of the metal-exchanged product is confirmed by the PXRD pattern, which reveals no formation of a separate phase and bears perfect agreement to that of the simulated pattern of 1 Cu (Figure S14 in the ). Clearly, all these observations firmly demonstrate a Zn­(II)→Cu­(II) exchange in SC-SC manner. As mentioned earlier, 1 Cu could also be synthesized solvothermally in low yields by treating Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O with H 4 L, and this product gave a structure same as that of 1 Cu . It should be mentioned here that Cu­(II)→Zn­(II) exchange does not proceed even with long exposure of 1 Cu to a concentrated DMF solution of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 M) at RT or under hot condition. Clearly, this behavior points to the greater thermodynamic stability of 1 Cu . Also, unlike Cu2+, other transition metal ions like Co2+ and Ni2+ cannot replace the Zn2+ ions of 1.
elements.clean_text: To our understanding, employment of Cu(II) SBUs should be fruitful, because unlike Zn(II), a d9 electronic state possesses ligand field stabilization energy. As the axial water ligand will be removed upon desolvation, the four coordination at the Cu(II) center will still hold a relatively stable configuration. Existence of large channels and availability of Zn2(CO2)4 SBUs and Zn12(CO2)24 SBBs provide us a platform to explore postsynthetic transmetalation in 1. Indeed, the crystals slowly change from colorless to green-blue in 24 h, when kept in DMF solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.05 M) at RT. The electron paramagnetic resonance spectrum of green-blue crystals demonstrates a successful metal replacement (Figure S12 in the ). Monitoring of the metal-exchange kinetics by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy revealed 70% and 95% replacement of Cu2+ in 2 and 6 d, respectively, while complete exchange took 7 d to occur (Figure S15 in the ). This is further supported by the X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy. The morphology of the pristine crystals was preserved throughout the metal-exchange process as corroborated from the optical microscopic observation (Figure S11 in the ). X-ray crystallographic investigation of the (Table S1 in the ) transmetalated product reveals identical structure (Figure S13 in the ) to that of 1, holding the molecular formula {[Cu2(L)(H2O)2]⋅(7DMF)⋅(1H2O)} n  (1  Cu ). However, the M⋅⋅⋅O distance increases from 1.965(4) Å in 1 to 2.144(6) Å in 1  Cu  (Table S2 in the ). The bulk phase transformation of the metal-exchanged product is confirmed by the PXRD pattern, which reveals no formation of a separate phase and bears perfect agreement to that of the simulated pattern of 1  Cu  (Figure S14 in the ). Clearly, all these observations firmly demonstrate a Zn(II)→Cu(II) exchange in SC-SC manner. As mentioned earlier, 1  Cu  could also be synthesized solvothermally in low yields by treating Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O with H  4  L, and this product gave a structure same as that of 1  Cu . It should be mentioned here that Cu(II)→Zn(II) exchange does not proceed even with long exposure of 1  Cu  to a concentrated DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5 M) at RT or under hot condition. Clearly, this behavior points to the greater thermodynamic stability of 1  Cu . Also, unlike Cu2+, other transition metal ions like Co2+ and Ni2+ cannot replace the Zn2+ ions of 1.

elements.content: The high thermal stability of 1 Cu is confirmed by the VTPXRD experiment, which reveals that the framework remains intact until 250 °C (Figure S16 in the ). We next examined the water stability of the metal-exchanged framework. As already discussed in the , the water molecules can easily attack the weak M–O bond in carboxylate MOFs leading to complete decomposition of the framework in the presence of moisture.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Water Stability of 1  Cu  

The high thermal stability of 1  Cu  is confirmed by the VTPXRD experiment, which reveals that the framework remains intact until 250 °C (Figure S16 in the ). We next examined the water stability of the metal-exchanged framework. As already discussed in the , the water molecules can easily attack the weak M-O bond in carboxylate MOFs leading to complete decomposition of the framework in the presence of moisture.

elements.content: Moisture sensitivity of 1 Cu was checked by allowing water vapor to diffuse into the crystals of 1 Cu at 298 K. The PXRD pattern of the sample measured at regular intervals showed no obvious change of the peak positions until 7 d of exposure to water vapor (), authenticating that the framework integrity is maintained. The hydrophobic nature of the framework was checked by H2O sorption isotherm at room temperature, which shows large hysteresis. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of the desolvated sample (1 Cu ′) shows negligible water uptake up to 0.85 bar (Figure S21 in the ), with a steep increase at higher relative pressure (p/p 0 > 0.9). This performance is similar to the activated carbon, which has a hydrophobic surface. In addition, N2 sorption measurements were used to examine the porosity of the MOF samples after soaking in water (vide infra). The water stability of 1 Cu can be explained on the basis of the following: (a) the Cu­(II)-SBUs possess increased ligand field stabilization energy that makes the ligand substitution processes less favorable (vide supra), and (b) functionalizing of ligand H 4 L with pendant fluorine creates a fluorine lining (hydrophobic) in the channel walls that imparts weak host–guest interactions between MOF walls and water molecules. As a result, the incoming water molecules tend to form a thin layer via H-bonding interactions outside the hydrophobic surface preventing water molecules to enter into channels and lead to collapse of the framework.

elements.content: The presence of porous channels in 1 Cu along with its thermal and water stability provide a perfect platform to examine the gas sorption properties. To generate the fully desolvated framework (1 Cu ′), crystals of 1 Cu were first immersed in EtOH for one week, followed by heating under high vacuum at 130 °C changing the color of the crystals to deep blue. At 77 K, the N2 sorption isotherm up to 1.0 bar pressure shows a type I isotherm () with slight hysteresis around 0.4 bar. The isotherm clearly indicates microporous nature of the framework, which can be further corroborated from the pore size distribution pattern (Figure S20 in the ). On the basis of the N2 adsorption studies, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume are found to be 1580 m2 g–1 and 0.97 cm3 g–1 respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Studies

The presence of porous channels in 1  Cu  along with its thermal and water stability provide a perfect platform to examine the gas sorption properties. To generate the fully desolvated framework (1  Cu  '), crystals of 1  Cu  were first immersed in EtOH for one week, followed by heating under high vacuum at 130 °C changing the color of the crystals to deep blue. At 77 K, the N2 sorption isotherm up to 1.0 bar pressure shows a type I isotherm () with slight hysteresis around 0.4 bar. The isotherm clearly indicates microporous nature of the framework, which can be further corroborated from the pore size distribution pattern (Figure S20 in the ). On the basis of the N2 adsorption studies, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume are found to be 1580 m2 g-1 and 0.97 cm3 g-1 respectively.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms of 1 Cu ′ at 77 K up to 1 bar pressure: (a) N2 and (b) H2.
elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption isotherms of 1  Cu  ' at 77 K up to 1 bar pressure: (a) N2 and (b) H2.

elements.content: Given the importance of developing a protocol for on-board storage of hydrogen gas, we next explored H2 storage capacity of 1 Cu ′. At 77 K, the H2 adsorption showed a type I isotherm without any hysteresis, where storage capacity reaches to 287.02 cm3 g–1 (2.56 wt %) up to 1 bar (b). Clearly, the value of H2 uptake in the present system is greater than that of MOF-5 (2.0%), Cu-BTT (2.42%), Cu­(peip) (2.51%), MOF-505 (2.47%), PCN-306 (2.50%), PMOF-3 (2.47%), NOTT-101 (2.52%), PCN-61 (2.25%), Fe-BTT (2.3%), and many other reported MOFs, or the well-known zeolite ZSM-5 (0.7 wt %; Table S3 in the ). The nature of the H2 adsorption isotherm suggests strong electrostatic interactions between H2 and fluorine as well as exposed Cu­(II) sites. Since the present H2 storage curve does not reach a saturation point at 1 bar, larger uptake capacities could be anticipated at higher pressures. Indeed, the H2 uptake capacity of 1 Cu ′ reaches to 454.23 cm3 g–1 (4.05 wt %) at 13 bar of pressure (Figure S17, ).

elements.content: Next, CO2 capture potential of 1 Cu ′ up to 1 bar pressure was explored at 273 and 298 K. As shown in a, both the adsorption isotherms displayed type I behavior with no hysteresis, where the total CO2 uptake amounted to be 185 cm3 g–1 (36.36 wt %) and 106 cm3 g–1 (20.9 wt %) at 273 and 298 K, respectively.

elements.content: Though numerous PMOFs with high CO2 capture have been reported, the present result with 1 Cu ′ clearly outperforms most of the PMOFs based on bent tetracarboxylates and matches the performance of a handful of examples, exhibiting more than 30.0 wt % CO2 uptake at 273 K (Table S4 in the ). At the initial coverage, the Q st exhibits a maximum value of 39.51 kJ mol–1 (b), signifying a favorable interaction between CO2 molecules and the framework. Although this Q st value is less compared to some −NH2 groups containing PMOFs like NH2-MIL-53­(Al) (50 kJ/mol), CAU-1 (48 kJ/mol), bio-MOF-11 (45 kJ/mol), and TBA@bio-MOF-1 (55 kJ/mol), it is superior to those of Cu­(dImb) (39 kJ/mol), MIL-120 (38 kJ/mol), Co-MOF-74 (37 kJ/mol), TMA@bio-MOF-1 (35 kJ/mol), HKUST-1 (35 kJ/mol), CNT@Cu3(BTC)2 (34 kJ/mol), MOF-5 (34 kJ/mol), NOTT-140 (25 kJ/mol), and MIL-53­(Cr) (32 kJ/mol). The notable quadrupole moment and polarizability of CO2 molecules (13.4 × 10–40 C m2 and 26.3 × 10–25 cm3, respectively) leads to greater adsorbate–adsorbent interaction. At higher coverage, the binding affinity of CO2 decreases, as the favorable binding sites (unsaturated Cu2+ centers and −NH2 groups) become less accessible. This moderate enthalpy of adsorption provides not only a good affinity for CO2 capture but also points to the facile adsorbent regeneration without heating, which is a desired property for applications. More importantly, exposure of 1 Cu ′ to natural air with some degree of humidity for 7 d followed by activation (in a similar way as already discussed for the generation of 1 Cu ′) shows almost equal uptake for five cycles of CO2 adsorption–desorption experiments at 298 K (Figure S18 in the ). This indicates that 1 Cu ′ is potentially useful as an adsorbent for postcombustion industrial flue gases that contain a certain amount of moisture. To further confirm the efficiency of 1 Cu ′ under humid conditions, pore size distribution pattern of the pristine 1 Cu ′ and 1 Cu ′ after 7 d of exposure to the water vapor were checked. The results reveal good agreement in both the cases (Figure S20 in the ). Moreover, the nitrogen adsorption isotherms of 1 Cu ′ performed after exposure of the samples to the water vapor at different time intervals followed by activation show almost similar BET surface area and pore size distribution (Figures S19 and S20 in the ).

The CO2 selectivity over N2 and H2 are found to be 263 and 268, respectively.

elements.content: To our knowledge, only a few frameworks have shown the CO2/N2 selectivity of greater than 200. However, CH4 gas molecules with the polarizability (25.93 × 10–25 cm3) enter the pores moderately (41.80 cc/g at 273 K and up to 1 bar, (Figure S22 in the ), which accounts for the low CO2/CH4 selectivity of 7.68. Notably, at 44 bar and 303 K, the framework displays type I adsorption behavior (b), with a substantially high 11.7 wt % (164.70 cc/g) of methane uptake. This CH4 storage performance is superior or similar to some reported PMOFs: PCN-11 (14.0 wt %), CPO-27-Mg (13.7 wt %), MIL-53­(Al) (13.5 wt %), Ni-MOF-74 and CPO-27-Ni (11.9 wt %), Ni-MOF-74 (11.9 wt %), UMCM-1 (11.4 wt %), and MIL-100 (10.7 wt %), HKUST-1 (10.2 wt %), MIL-53­(Cr) (8.8 wt %), measured at different high pressures.

elements.content: PMOFs are expected to display superior shape and/or size selectivity of catalysis because the catalytic reactions occur within their cavities. The excellent stability of 1 Cu ′ against heat and moisture together with the presence of open Cu­(II) coordination sites, optimized pores, and −NH2 group decorated channels fulfill the essential prerequisites of the framework to act as a heterogeneous catalyst. Frameworks built with Cu­(II) have been proven to catalyze many organic transformations such as Michael addition, oxidation, cross-coupling reactions, and so on.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Activities of 1  Cu  ' in the Biginelli Reactions

PMOFs are expected to display superior shape and/or size selectivity of catalysis because the catalytic reactions occur within their cavities. The excellent stability of 1  Cu  ' against heat and moisture together with the presence of open Cu(II) coordination sites, optimized pores, and -NH2 group decorated channels fulfill the essential prerequisites of the framework to act as a heterogeneous catalyst. Frameworks built with Cu(II) have been proven to catalyze many organic transformations such as Michael addition, oxidation, cross-coupling reactions, and so on.

elements.content: Presently, we were interested to explore the heterogeneous catalytic activity of 1 Cu ′ toward three-component Biginelli coupling reactions involving urea, ethyl acetoacetate, and aromatic aldehydes to give dihydroprimidinones () that are important precursors for pharmaceuticals.

In a typical experiment, the mixture of benzaldehyde (1.0 mmol), urea (1.5 mmol), and ethyl acetoacetate (2.0 mmol) was reacted at 60 °C in the presence of 1 Cu ′ (10 wt %) under nitrogen atmosphere. The yield of the product, ethyl 6-methyl-2-oxo-4-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate, for the model reaction was 86% (, entry 1) with turnover number and turnover frequency of 48.05 and 24.03, respectively. The reaction could be easily monitored by thin-layer chromatography, and when it was complete, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed successively with CH2Cl2 and acetone, followed by heating under vacuum at 120 °C (8 h) to regenerate the active catalyst. The framework integrity of the recovered catalyst was maintained even after four cycles, as confirmed from the unchanged PXRD patterns (Figure S37 in the ). Formation of the desired dihydroprimidinone was confirmed by the 1H NMR and 13C NMR (Figures S23–S36 in the ) data. The possible effect of catalyst loading in the model reaction was investigated using different amounts of 1 Cu ′, which revealed that the yield increased with increasing the amount of the catalyst (Table S5, ). The results () of the catalytic activity of 1 Cu ′ reveal that the yield is quite good both with electron-withdrawing as well as electron-donating groups attached to aldehyde molecules. Importantly, when the substrate is a bulky aldehyde, the reaction proceeds slowly and produces only low yield (). This observation points to the fact that sterically encumbered aldehydes do not fit inside the framework cavity. The nature of the catalysis reactions can be explained on the basis of formation of an intermediate carbocation, similar to the mechanism proposed by Sweet. The heterogeneous behavior of the catalyst is established in each case by hot filtration of the reaction mixture and probing the catalytic activity of the filtrate that gave negative results.

The reaction could be easily monitored by thin-layer chromatography, and when it was complete, the catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed successively with CH2Cl2 and acetone, followed by heating under vacuum at 120 °C (8 h) to regenerate the active catalyst. The framework integrity of the recovered catalyst was maintained even after four cycles, as confirmed from the unchanged PXRD patterns (Figure S37 in the ). Formation of the desired dihydroprimidinone was confirmed by the 1H NMR and 13C NMR (Figures S23-S36 in the ) data. The possible effect of catalyst loading in the model reaction was investigated using different amounts of 1  Cu  ', which revealed that the yield increased with increasing the amount of the catalyst (Table S5, ). The results () of the catalytic activity of 1  Cu  ' reveal that the yield is quite good both with electron-withdrawing as well as electron-donating groups attached to aldehyde molecules. Importantly, when the substrate is a bulky aldehyde, the reaction proceeds slowly and produces only low yield (). This observation points to the fact that sterically encumbered aldehydes do not fit inside the framework cavity. The nature of the catalysis reactions can be explained on the basis of formation of an intermediate carbocation, similar to the mechanism proposed by Sweet. The heterogeneous behavior of the catalyst is established in each case by hot filtration of the reaction mixture and probing the catalytic activity of the filtrate that gave negative results.

elements.content: By using a bent and rigid angular tetracarboxylate H 4 L incorporating pendant fluorine and amine moieties, a 3D Zn­(II)-MOF has been synthesized. This framework is found to be unstable on removing solvent molecules from the framework by heating. Interestingly, it undergoes SC-SC transmetalation reaction cleanly with Cu­(II) to afford an isostructural framework 1 Cu . This framework is found to be thermally quite stable, which allows generation of the solvent-free porous framework (1 Cu ′) with coordinatively unsaturated metal centers. The activated framework exhibits microporous nature with significant adsorption for H2, CO2, and CH4. Also, 1 Cu ′ exhibits high water stability and selective CO2 adsorption over H2, N2, and CH4 at 273 K, rendering it potentially important for applications toward CO2 sequestration under humid conditions. Furthermore, the presence of unsaturated Cu­(II) centers and porous cavities in 1 Cu ′ can be exploited for the heterogeneous catalysis of size-selective Biginelli condensation reactions to afford 3,4-dihydropyrimidines that have broad applications in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By using a bent and rigid angular tetracarboxylate H  4  L incorporating pendant fluorine and amine moieties, a 3D Zn(II)-MOF has been synthesized. This framework is found to be unstable on removing solvent molecules from the framework by heating. Interestingly, it undergoes SC-SC transmetalation reaction cleanly with Cu(II) to afford an isostructural framework 1  Cu . This framework is found to be thermally quite stable, which allows generation of the solvent-free porous framework (1  Cu  ') with coordinatively unsaturated metal centers. The activated framework exhibits microporous nature with significant adsorption for H2, CO2, and CH4. Also, 1  Cu  ' exhibits high water stability and selective CO2 adsorption over H2, N2, and CH4 at 273 K, rendering it potentially important for applications toward CO2 sequestration under humid conditions. Furthermore, the presence of unsaturated Cu(II) centers and porous cavities in 1  Cu  ' can be exploited for the heterogeneous catalysis of size-selective Biginelli condensation reactions to afford 3,4-dihydropyrimidines that have broad applications in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals.

The details of physicochemical characterization and single-crystal X-ray investigation are given in the .

Synthetic Methodology

The tetracarboxylic acid ligand H 4 L was synthesized following a reported procedure as illustrated in .

Synthesis of Tetraester (<bold>III</bold>)

To a 15 mL dimethylformamide (DMF) solution of 2,6-dibromo-4-fluoroaniline (1 g, 0.004 mol) and (3,5-bis­(ethoxycarbonyl)­phenyl) boronic acid (2.39 g, 0.009 mol), a 10 mL aqueous solution of Na2CO3 (2.12 g, 0.02 mol) and palladium acetate (10 mg) was added. The mixture was allowed to heat at 80 °C for 8 h and then cooled to room temperature. Upon extraction with ethyl acetate, it was washed thrice with water and passed through anhydrous Na2SO4. Removal of solvent in a rotary evaporator afforded the crude product as a yellow solid. It was purified using silica gel (100–200 mesh) column chromatography with ethyl acetate/n-hexane (1:9, v/v) as the eluent that gave ∼600 mg of light yellow solid of III (yield ≈ 29%). mp: 175 °C (uncorrected); 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) = 1.42 (t, 12H), 3.55 (s, 2H) 4.43 (q, 8H), 6.92 (s, 2H), 8.34 (d, 4H), 8.69 (d, 2H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) = 14.43, 29.78, 61.61, 118.67, 126.28, 129.73, 130.62, 131.81, 134.59, 140.21, 165.75. Anal. Calcd (%) for C30H30FNO8: C, 65.33; H, 5.48; N, 2.54. Found: C, 65.50; H, 5.75; N, 2.50.

Synthesis of H<sub>4</sub>L

The tetra-ester was hydrolyzed by heating at 80 °C with concentrated H2SO4 (96%) in methanol medium with vigorous stirring overnight. Then 10 mL of water was added dropwise at a slow rate to keep the reaction temperature within ∼95 °C. After it was heated 24 h further, it was poured into the crushed ice to obtain a white precipitate. The precipitate was collected and washed thoroughly with water to remove H2SO4. The white product was dried to obtain 600 mg (∼96%) of the tetracarboxylic acid H 4 L. mp >300 °C; 1H NMR (500 MHz, deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6)): δ (ppm) = 4.35 (s, 2H), 7.08 (d, 2H), 8.19 (d, 4H), 8.44 (d, 2H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ (ppm) = 122.88, 130.85, 133.99, 135.61, 137.24, 139.26, 145.52, 147.11, 171.89. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS): m/z (100%) 438.0605 [M–1]−. Anal. Calcd (%) for C22H14FNO8: C, 60.14; H, 3.21; N, 3.19. Found: C, 60.50; H, 3.50; N, 3.28.

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·(5DMF)·(2H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (L = L<sup>4–</sup>) (<bold>1</bold>)

In a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, H 4 L (20 mg, 0.05 mmol) and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (28 mg, 0.1 mmol) were added to a mixed solvent of 2 mL of DMF and 1 mL of EtOH followed by heating at 90 °C under autogenous pressure for 72 h. When cooled to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C h–1, colorless, block-shaped crystals of 1 were obtained in ∼50% yield. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR; KBr, cm–1): 3447b, 3094s, 2929s, 1657s, 1525s, 1438m, 1107s, 623s. Anal. Calcd (%) for C37H53FN6O17Zn2: C, 44.28; H, 5.32; N, 8.37. Found: C, 44.50; H, 5.15; N, 8.15.

Synthesis of {[Cu<sub>2</sub>(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·(5DMF)·(5H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold> <sub> <bold>Cu</bold> </sub>) via Transmetalation

After the crystals of 1 were thoroughly washed in DMF, they were kept in a DMF solution containing 0.05 M Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O for 7 d, which afforded 1 Cu without any loss of crystallinity. The morphology of the crystals remained unaltered upon transmetalation (Figure S11 in the ). FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3435­(br), 3380­(br), 2940 (s), 1674(s), 1630(s), 1372(s), 1091(s), 728(s). Anal. Calcd (%) for C37H59N6O20FCu2: C, 42.16; H, 5.64; N, 7.97. Found: C, 41.90; H, 5.20 3; N, 7.75.

cln_elements.content:
A partially fluorinated, angular tetracarboxylic acid linker (H 4 L) incorporating a pendant amine moiety forms a three-dimensional Zn­(II) framework, 1. The structure consists of paddle-wheel Zn2(CO2)4 secondary building units (SBUs) and Zn12(CO2)24 supramolecular building blocks (SBBs). Thermal stability of 1 is found to be low. However, it undergoes transmetalation reaction with Cu­(II) at room temperature without losing crystallinity affording an isostructural framework, 1 Cu . Framework 1 Cu is thermally robust and allows generation of the solvent-free porous framework 1 Cu ′ upon activation with coordinatively unsaturated metal centers. Framework 1 Cu ′ exhibits water stability and at 77 K, adsorbs 2.56 wt % of H2 up to 1 bar that significantly increases to 4.01 wt % at 13 bar. Also, this framework gives a high adsorption of 164.70 cc/g of CH4 (11.7 wt %) at 303 K and 60 bar. The channel surfaces decorated with −NH2 group and unsaturated metal centers in 1 Cu ′ allow a promising 36.4 wt % of CO2 adsorption at 1 bar and 273 K. Moreover, it exhibits pronounced selectivity of CO2 adsorption over N2 and H2 at 273 K. Finally, the versatility of 1 Cu ′ is shown by its excellent heterogeneous catalytic activity in the Biginelli coupling reactions involving an aldehyde, urea, and ethylacetoacetate to afford dihydroprimidinones.

A 3D, thermally less-stable Zn­(II)-framework (1) undergoes single-crystal to single-crystal transmetalation with Cu­(II) to afford isostructural 1 Cu . Unlike 1, the Cu­(II) analogue is thermally stable and can be activated by heating to get 1 Cu ′, which exhibits water stability and adsorbs 2.56 wt % of H2 at 1 bar. It exhibits pronounced CO2 selectivity over N2 and H2 and catalyzes the three-component Biginelli coupling reaction.

Gas Adsorption Studies

The presence of porous channels in 1 Cu along with its thermal and water stability provide a perfect platform to examine the gas sorption properties. To generate the fully desolvated framework (1 Cu ′), crystals of 1 Cu were first immersed in EtOH for one week, followed by heating under high vacuum at 130 °C changing the color of the crystals to deep blue. At 77 K, the N2 sorption isotherm up to 1.0 bar pressure shows a type I isotherm () with slight hysteresis around 0.4 bar. The isotherm clearly indicates microporous nature of the framework, which can be further corroborated from the pore size distribution pattern (Figure S20 in the ). On the basis of the N2 adsorption studies, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume are found to be 1580 m2 g–1 and 0.97 cm3 g–1 respectively.

Given the importance of developing a protocol for on-board storage of hydrogen gas, we next explored H2 storage capacity of 1 Cu ′. At 77 K, the H2 adsorption showed a type I isotherm without any hysteresis, where storage capacity reaches to 287.02 cm3 g–1 (2.56 wt %) up to 1 bar (b). Clearly, the value of H2 uptake in the present system is greater than that of MOF-5 (2.0%), Cu-BTT (2.42%), Cu­(peip) (2.51%), MOF-505 (2.47%), PCN-306 (2.50%), PMOF-3 (2.47%), NOTT-101 (2.52%), PCN-61 (2.25%), Fe-BTT (2.3%), and many other reported MOFs, or the well-known zeolite ZSM-5 (0.7 wt %; Table S3 in the ). The nature of the H2 adsorption isotherm suggests strong electrostatic interactions between H2 and fluorine as well as exposed Cu­(II) sites. Since the present H2 storage curve does not reach a saturation point at 1 bar, larger uptake capacities could be anticipated at higher pressures. Indeed, the H2 uptake capacity of 1 Cu ′ reaches to 454.23 cm3 g–1 (4.05 wt %) at 13 bar of pressure (Figure S17, ).

Next, CO2 capture potential of 1 Cu ′ up to 1 bar pressure was explored at 273 and 298 K. As shown in a, both the adsorption isotherms displayed type I behavior with no hysteresis, where the total CO2 uptake amounted to be 185 cm3 g–1 (36.36 wt %) and 106 cm3 g–1 (20.9 wt %) at 273 and 298 K, respectively.

Indeed, the H2 uptake capacity of 1  Cu  ' reaches to 454.23 cm3 g-1 (4.05 wt %) at 13 bar of pressure (Figure S17, ).

Next, CO2 capture potential of 1  Cu  ' up to 1 bar pressure was explored at 273 and 298 K. As shown in a, both the adsorption isotherms displayed type I behavior with no hysteresis, where the total CO2 uptake amounted to be 185 cm3 g-1 (36.36 wt %) and 106 cm3 g-1 (20.9 wt %) at 273 and 298 K, respectively.
